results.title: From 5 to 7.30
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Read and American Temperance Society
results.brief_description: Shows the effect that drinking parents can have on their children. Joe is deeply disturbed when one of his schoolmates, because of his drinking, is involved in a motor car accident. His conviction is strengthened because he see the results of social drinking and “the cocktail hour” in his own home, and in that of his girl-friend. He seeks advice from his coach at school, and attends a lecture by Dr Andrew C. Ivy, which results in his decision to “leave it alone”.

results.title: Frogs and how they live
results.brief_description: Uses close-up photography toreveal key concepts about this familiar amphibian. The process of metamorphosis, hibernation and details of major body parts are also shown. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Frog went a-courtin'
results.brief_description: A 400 year old Scottish ballad, which tells the tale of the courtship of Mr Frog and Miss Mouse. Sung by John Langstaff, the song is repeated so the audience can join in by following the verses as they appear on the screen. Music by Arthur Kleiner and illustrated by Feodor Rojankovsky.

results.title: Frog dreaming
results.creator_credit: Brian Trenchard-Smith, Barbi Taylor and Middle Reef Productions
results.brief_description: Something’s alive at the bottom of an uncharted pond, and the 10 year old adventurer Cody (Henry Thomas of ET) is determined to find it. The action of this children’s movie (involving Aboriginal magic) is set in a remote town in southern Australia. The real adventure is Trenchard-Smith’s rediscovery of boyhood, with all its inventiveness, innocence and independent fearless strength.

results.title: Frocks on the docks

results.brief_description: Liz Orr talks about the dress she bought between curtain calls, the fundraiser for Heather Osland’s defence and the fight to keep the union strong on Melbourne’s docks.

results.title: Fritz the cat (E)
results.creator_credit: Ralph Bakshi, Steve Krantz and Fritz Productions for Aurica Finance Co
results.brief_description: The X-rated cartoon based on the characters from Robert Crumb’s comic strip became the animated world’s Portnoy’s Complaint, being the first animated feature in the history of motion pictures to contain nudity and four-letter words. Since its release, it has become an adult “classic” - a film everyone wants to see simply because it was naughty and often banned. In the 1960’s flower power era of sex, drugs and rock and roll, Fritz is the coolest cat in New York - poet, muso, dope-smoker and sex hound. In his East village apartment, he and his band engage in an orgy and are raided by the Police. He sets fire to his school, incites the local blacks to riot against white oppression and then leaves the Big Apple for the open road where he becomes ensnared by terrorist bikies! Features a rock musical especially written for the film and the voices of Skip Hinnant, Rosetta LeNoire, John McCurry and Phil Seuling.

creators_primary.name: Fritz Productions for Aurica Finance Co

results.title: Fritz Lang
results.brief_description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.

constellations_primary.name: One of the first auteurs
constellations_primary.description: A progenitor of modern film genres such as sci-fi, psychological thriller and serial killer films decades before such terms were coined, Austrian-born director Fritz Lang also enjoyed the occasional on-screen meta-moment.

results.description: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). From a technologically advanced but nightmarish future to mad scientists and the first robot in a feature, Metropolis has influenced so much of what we see on-screen today. At two hours and 33 minutes, it was also one of the longest films ever made at the time. Critics were sceptical at first, but it’s now considered groundbreaking, particularly for its production design and costumes. Those two elements have inspired C-3PO in Star Wars, Kylie Minogue’s robotic stage costumes and the futuristic city in Blade Runner. If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.
description_for_label: Fritz Lang was a visionary German director who established many science fiction tropes with his silent masterpiece Metropolis (1927). From a technologically advanced but nightmarish future to mad scientists and the first robot in a feature, Metropolis has influenced so much of what we see on-screen today. At two hours and 33 minutes, it was also one of the longest films ever made at the time. Critics were sceptical at first, but it’s now considered groundbreaking, particularly for its production design and costumes. Those two elements have inspired C-3PO in Star Wars, Kylie Minogue’s robotic stage costumes and the futuristic city in Blade Runner. If that wasn’t enough, Lang’s seminal crime drama M (1931) was an early progenitor of psychological thrillers and serial killer films.
